channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Syrian rebels take Hama, a second major city, in another blow to Assad
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Mohamad El Chamaa
item.description: The Islamist rebels’ breakneck advance has redrawn the country’s frontlines and revealed the fragility of the government’s security forces.

item.title: Live Briefing: New efforts underway to reach Gaza ceasefire deal, officials say; Syrian rebels take new city
item.dc:creator: Mohamad El Chamaa, Niha Masih, Vivian Ho, Kareem Fahim, Bryan Pietsch, Sammy Westfall, Hazem Balousha
item.description: A Syrian Islamist rebel group said Thursday it has entered neighborhoods in the central city of Hama.

item.title: Macron rules out resigning, will tap new prime minister, after government falls
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis, Annabelle Timsit
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron said he would name a new prime minister within days and railed against the far-right and left factions that toppled the government.

item.title: Two arrested in Romania in stabbing of Iranian journalist in London
item.dc:creator: Greg Miller
item.description: The men are suspected of carrying out a stabbing attack on an Iranian journalist in London on behalf of Tehran.

item.title: Renewed calls for ceasefire after IDF recovers hostage’s body
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker, Lior Soroka

item.title: A viral song becomes the latest symbol of Venezuela’s crackdown
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt
item.description: A Venezuelan anthem reclaiming a pejorative term has gone viral but also drawn backlash from President Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Israeli strike on designated safe zone in Gaza kills 20
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Claire Parker, Hajar Harb

item.title: Trump’s Middle East envoy launches effort at Gaza ceasefire
item.dc:creator: John Hudson

item.title: Revenge, fire and destruction: A year of Israeli soldiers’ videos from Gaza
item.dc:creator: Loveday Morris, Sarah Cahlan, Jonathan Baran, Louisa Loveluck

item.title: As lawmakers move to impeach South Korean President Yoon, what happens next?
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett, Michelle Lee
item.description: Calls are growing for South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol’s ouster after he declared then rescinded martial law. Here’s how an impeachment would work.

item.title: Iran is sending regional fighters to Syria. Can they save Assad again?
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Suzan Haidamous, Mustafa Salim

item.title: Amnesty says Israel committing acts of genocide in Gaza. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Missy Ryan

item.title: Amnesty says Israel committing acts of genocide in Gaza. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Louisa Loveluck, Missy Ryan
item.description: The declaration by one of the world’s most prominent rights organizations is likely to intensify a debate that has raged for months over Israel’s conduct in Gaza.

item.title: A surprising turn in Syria's civil war
item.dc:creator: Peter Bresnan, Savannah Robinson, Ariel Plotnick, Rennie Svirnovskiy, Monica Campbell, Reena Flores, Lucy Perkins
item.description: In the past week, the civil war in Syria reignited. Islamist rebels seized control of Aleppo, triggering a new phase in a years-long civil war. The Post’s Middle East bureau chief, Kareem Fahim, talks with host Elahe Izadi about why this moment matters.

item.title: French government collapsed after no-confidence vote. What happens now?
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis, Anthony Faiola
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron must seek a new prime minister after Michel Barnier’s administration became the shortest-serving in the modern French republic.

item.title: Iran is sending regional fighters to Syria. Can they save Assad again?
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Suzan Haidamous, Mustafa Salim
item.description: Fighters from Hezbollah and Iraq’s Shiite militias have deployed to Syria to support government forces, but it’s unclear if they are capable of turning the tide.

item.title: Battles rage around Syria’s Hama as airstrikes hit hospitals, journalists
item.dc:creator: Ali Haj Suleiman , Kareem Fahim
item.description: A group of Syrian journalists headed toward Hama were hit by an airstrike, killing photographer Anas Alkharboutli.

item.title: South Korea’s martial law crisis stirs memories of 1980 Gwangju massacre
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Ables
item.description: In the uncertain hours early Wednesday, many recalled the nation’s last martial law, which came after a coup installed a military dictator and triggered a deadly uprising.

item.title: U.S. watches warily as key Asian ally descends into political chaos
item.dc:creator: Karen DeYoung, Ellen Nakashima
item.description: The president of South Korea’s declaration of martial law caught Washington by surprise.

item.title: South Korean opposition moves to impeach president after remarkable misstep
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee, Kelly Kasulis Cho, Niha Masih
item.description: Lawmakers could vote to impeach Yoon Suk Yeol as soon as Friday. Regardless of the outcome, it is clear that the president’s political future is in grave doubt.

item.title: After long wait for an egg, keepers discover Maggie the penguin is male
item.dc:creator: Leo Sands
item.description: Keepers at Birdland Park and Gardens, England, renamed the prized female king penguin “Magnus” after DNA testing found that he was incorrectly sexed as female.

item.title: Georgia protests gather momentum after pro-Russia party suspends E.U. bid
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: By suspending talks with the E.U., the party was decisively pivoting to Russia and away from its European aspirations — one of the few goals most Georgians agree on.

item.title: What caused the Notre Dame fire? The latest as the cathedral reopens.
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Timsit
item.description: Here’s what to know about the Notre Dame fire investigation, what was lost and when the public can visit.

item.title: Four things to know about South Korean President Yoon as impeachment looms
item.dc:creator: Michelle Lee, Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Yoon Suk Yeol was a career prosecutor who made his first foray into politics when he became the People Power Party’s presidential candidate in 2021.

item.description: The country reacted in anger and shock after President Yoon Suk Yeol abruptly called for martial law Tuesday night, only to backtrack hours later.

item.dc:creator: Kelly Kasulis Cho

item.description: Sudan is coping with the apathy of a failing international system.
